values.description:
Modified the resampling algorithm to correctly support stepMode=True in pyqtgraph plots. This plot mode requires that len(x) = len(y)+1 (array dimensions were apparently not enforced in prior versions)

Resolves #2
values.title: Fixed compatibility with pyqtgraph v0.9.10

summary.raw:

Resolves #2

values.description:
This typo raised an exception whenever a shot was added.

```
#!python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/rander/labscript_suite/runviewer/__main__.py", line 324, in on_shot_selection_changed
    self.plot_items[channel][shot].setPen(pg.mkPen(QColor(colour()), width=2))
TypeError: arguments did not match any overloaded call:
  QColor(Qt.GlobalColor): argument 1 has unexpected type 'NoneType'
  QColor(int): too many arguments
  QColor(QVariant): argument 1 has unexpected type 'NoneType'
  QColor(): argument 1 has unexpected type 'NoneType'
  QColor(int, int, int, int alpha=255): argument 1 has unexpected type 'NoneType'
```
values.title: Fixed typo in color argument of QColor in on_shot_selection_changed.

values.description:
This pull request along with it's sister pull requests introduces qtutil's new abstraction layer for Qt. This abstraction layer is supposed to act like PyQt5. A few adjustments needed to be made so things don't break.

This pull request should also bring PyQt5 compatibility but this should be experimental at first so reviewing should not include this as a criterium for approval. (This has been discussed [here](https://pstarkey.github.io/bitbucket-archive/#!/pull-requests/1/pyqt5/diff#comment-41775691))

To test this one needs to also pull from my qtutils repo [here](https://bitbucket.org/PhyNerd/qtutils/).
values.title: qtutils 2.0.0 support and experimental PyQt5 support

summary.raw:
This pull request along with it's sister pull requests introduces qtutil's new abstraction layer for Qt. This abstraction layer is supposed to act like PyQt5. A few adjustments needed to be made so things don't break.

This pull request should also bring PyQt5 compatibility but this should be experimental at first so reviewing should not include this as a criterium for approval. (This has been discussed [here](https://pstarkey.github.io/bitbucket-archive/#!/pull-requests/1/pyqt5/diff#comment-41775691))

To test this one needs to also pull from my qtutils repo [here](https://bitbucket.org/PhyNerd/qtutils/).
summary.html:
This pull request along with it's sister pull requests introduces qtutil's new abstraction layer for Qt. This abstraction layer is supposed to act like PyQt5. A few adjustments needed to be made so things don't break.

This pull request should also bring PyQt5 compatibility but this should be experimental at first so reviewing should not include this as a criterium for approval. (This has been discussed here)

To test this one needs to also pull from my qtutils repo here.

values.description: This adds platform support for macos.  ```platform.architecture() ``` returns ```('64bit', '')``` under mac so thats why ini.py now has a line ```elif arch == ('64bit', '')```. I also tried the unix files before compiling new ones and they don't work for mac.
values.title: Compiled resampler for mac

summary.raw: This adds platform support for macos.  ```platform.architecture() ``` returns ```('64bit', '')``` under mac so thats why ini.py now has a line ```elif arch == ('64bit', '')```. I also tried the unix files before compiling new ones and they don't work for mac.
summary.html: This adds platform support for macos. platform.architecture() returns ('64bit', '') under mac so thats why ini.py now has a line elif arch == ('64bit', ''). I also tried the unix files before compiling new ones and they don't work for mac.

values.description:
This adds the ability to save/restore channel configurations. Both actions can be triggered from the file menu. On restore channels  get checked/unchecked according to the config if they are already in the channels menu. If not they get added to the channel menu and are disabled. This allow for loading channel configs before any shots are loaded.

This fixes issue #15
values.title: Channel configs

summary.raw:

On restore channels  get checked/unchecked according to the config if they are already in the channels menu. If not they get added to the channel menu and are disabled. This allow for loading channel configs before any shots are loaded.

This fixes issue #15
summary.html:
This adds the ability to save/restore channel configurations. Both actions can be triggered from the file menu. On restore channels get checked/unchecked according to the config if they are already in the channels menu. If not they get added to the channel menu and are disabled. This allow for loading channel configs before any shots are loaded.

This fixes issue #15

values.description: Today I was doing some python 3 testing and run files compiled with python3 resulted in a unicode master pseudoclock name \(Python 2 ones did not\). I'm not quite sure when attributes are unicode and when they are byte strings so I added a check before trying to decode to prevent a exception.
values.title: Minor Python 3 fix

summary.raw: Today I was doing some python 3 testing and run files compiled with python3 resulted in a unicode master pseudoclock name \(Python 2 ones did not\). I'm not quite sure when attributes are unicode and when they are byte strings so I added a check before trying to decode to prevent a exception.
summary.html: Today I was doing some python 3 testing and run files compiled with python3 resulted in a unicode master pseudoclock name (Python 2 ones did not). I'm not quite sure when attributes are unicode and when they are byte strings so I added a check before trying to decode to prevent a exception.

values.description:
Ported `resample` extension to Cython for easier maintenance and uniformity with other extensions (i.e. rfblaster extensions). I split off the platform independence stuff into a separate project called [`autocython`](http://autocython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) since I end up writing exactly the same code to do this any time I do anything with Cython. `autocython` keeps all the compiled extensions in the same directory with a platform-specific suffix (only on Python 2, since Python 3 names extension .so and .pyd files with its own platform-specific suffixes already). You can compile for a new platform either by running runviewer (the compile will happen at import), or by running `python -m autocython` in the extension directory. I'll use the same method to get the rfblaster code compiling for Python 2 and 3. This introduces a dependence on `autocython`, which I can add as a dependency to the labscript installer, and I've added a check to `runviewer.resample` prompting anyone updating to install `autocython` from pip.

Commits:

* Ported resample extension to Cython, and add run-time compilation attempt
    for platforms that have not had the extension precompiled.

    The port is a straight copy-paste of resample4 from `__main__.py` with replacements
    of len() and [-1] with the known length N of the arrays and N - 1 respectively.

    Compilation no longer has a numpy dendendency since Cython has its own arrays.

    The Cython extension does not hold the GIL, whereas I believe the C extension did.

* Use autocython for platform abstraction and auto compiling.

* Compile for linux

* Compile for Windows

* Compile for mac
values.title: Port resample to Cython

summary.raw:
Ported `resample` extension to Cython for easier maintenance and uniformity with other extensions (i.e. rfblaster extensions). I split off the platform independence stuff into a separate project called [`autocython`](http://autocython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) since I end up writing exactly the same code to do this any time I do anything with Cython. `autocython` keeps all the compiled extensions in the same directory with a platform-specific suffix (only on Python 2, since Python 3 names extension .so and .pyd files with its own platform-specific suffixes already). You can compile for a new platform either by running runviewer (the compile will happen at import), or by running `python -m autocython` in the extension directory. I'll use the same method to get the rfblaster code compiling for Python 2 and 3. This introduces a dependence on `autocython`, which I can add as a dependency to the labscript installer, and I've added a check to `runviewer.resample` prompting anyone updating to install `autocython` from pip.

Commits:

* Ported resample extension to Cython, and add run-time compilation attempt
    for platforms that have not had the extension precompiled.

    The port is a straight copy-paste of resample4 from `__main__.py` with replacements
    of len() and [-1] with the known length N of the arrays and N - 1 respectively.

    Compilation no longer has a numpy dendendency since Cython has its own arrays.

    The Cython extension does not hold the GIL, whereas I believe the C extension did.

* Use autocython for platform abstraction and auto compiling.

* Compile for linux

* Compile for Windows

* Compile for mac
summary.html:
Ported resample extension to Cython for easier maintenance and uniformity with other extensions (i.e. rfblaster extensions). I split off the platform independence stuff into a separate project called autocython since I end up writing exactly the same code to do this any time I do anything with Cython. autocython keeps all the compiled extensions in the same directory with a platform-specific suffix (only on Python 2, since Python 3 names extension .so and .pyd files with its own platform-specific suffixes already). You can compile for a new platform either by running runviewer (the compile will happen at import), or by running python -m autocython in the extension directory. I'll use the same method to get the rfblaster code compiling for Python 2 and 3. This introduces a dependence on autocython, which I can add as a dependency to the labscript installer, and I've added a check to runviewer.resample prompting anyone updating to install autocython from pip.

Commits:

  • Ported resample extension to Cython, and add run-time compilation attempt for platforms that have not had the extension precompiled.

    The port is a straight copy-paste of resample4 from __main__.py with replacements of len() and [-1] with the known length N of the arrays and N - 1 respectively.

    Compilation no longer has a numpy dendendency since Cython has its own arrays.

    The Cython extension does not hold the GIL, whereas I believe the C extension did.

  • Use autocython for platform abstraction and auto compiling.

  • Compile for linux

  • Compile for Windows

  • Compile for mac

values.description:
Moved the "hidden\_plot" \(which actually needs to be always visible\) so that the reset time axis button always works, even when you have a large number of plots visible and you have scrolled down the list. This should fix #19.

runviewer now looks like this:

![runviewer\_issue\_19.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/69A8Gq/images/511316635-runviewer_issue_19.png 'runviewer\_issue\_19.png')

values.description:
The changes in this pull request allow to rescale the time axis in shots. After rescaling the currently selected markers will be spaced evenly. This allows for a better visibility of changes on very small or large time scales. The rescaling can be switched on and off at any time with a simple button in the ui.

Here is a example of a shot with and without non linear time:

‌

![before.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgkE5Ke/images/2358217092-before.png 'before.png')

![after.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgkE5Ke/images/1900538582-after.png 'after.png')
values.title: Non linear Time

values.description:
Resolves issue #24, implementing extended nonlinear time functionality. The user can now click and drag on the top section of markers to move them around. This re-scales time in the region to the left of the moved marker, translating later times. When changing from one set of markers to another, the current scaling is unchanged. When removing markers, time goes back to being linear.
There were also a few bugs in the current nonlinear time implementation when removing shots, turning off markers, or reverting to linear time, which have now been resolved.

To implement this functionality, I have also set runviewer to automatically insert markers at t=0 and at the end time of the currently selected experiment. The time-axis autoscale functionality has also been extended to ensure that it behaves as expected. I've also changed the icons on the buttons used for auto-scaling and changing marker spacing, to try to make them as intuitive as possible with the new set of features.

Known issues:

* Graph drawing can be glitchy when rescaling. Graphs are also redrawn when changing markers, even though they don't need to be.'

* Sometimes markers begin behaving weirdly, e.g. markers to the right of the one being used moving the wrong way or too quickly, or markers getting out of order. To 'reset' them you can change the markers selection to none, then back again. This seems to happen most when markers are moved by hand quickly.

I'm not sure if these issues are showstoppers, but if anyone has suggestions to fix them let me know!
values.title: New Nonlinear time

summary.raw:
Resolves issue #24, implementing extended nonlinear time functionality. The user can now click and drag on the top section of markers to move them around. This re-scales time in the region to the left of the moved marker, translating later times. When changing from one set of markers to another, the current scaling is unchanged. When removing markers, time goes back to being linear.
There were also a few bugs in the current nonlinear time implementation when removing shots, turning off markers, or reverting to linear time, which have now been resolved.

To implement this functionality, I have also set runviewer to automatically insert markers at t=0 and at the end time of the currently selected experiment. The time-axis autoscale functionality has also been extended to ensure that it behaves as expected. I've also changed the icons on the buttons used for auto-scaling and changing marker spacing, to try to make them as intuitive as possible with the new set of features.

Known issues:

* Graph drawing can be glitchy when rescaling. Graphs are also redrawn when changing markers, even though they don't need to be.'

* Sometimes markers begin behaving weirdly, e.g. markers to the right of the one being used moving the wrong way or too quickly, or markers getting out of order. To 'reset' them you can change the markers selection to none, then back again. This seems to happen most when markers are moved by hand quickly.

I'm not sure if these issues are showstoppers, but if anyone has suggestions to fix them let me know!
summary.html:
Resolves issue #24, implementing extended nonlinear time functionality. The user can now click and drag on the top section of markers to move them around. This re-scales time in the region to the left of the moved marker, translating later times. When changing from one set of markers to another, the current scaling is unchanged. When removing markers, time goes back to being linear. There were also a few bugs in the current nonlinear time implementation when removing shots, turning off markers, or reverting to linear time, which have now been resolved.

To implement this functionality, I have also set runviewer to automatically insert markers at t=0 and at the end time of the currently selected experiment. The time-axis autoscale functionality has also been extended to ensure that it behaves as expected. I've also changed the icons on the buttons used for auto-scaling and changing marker spacing, to try to make them as intuitive as possible with the new set of features.

Known issues:

  • Graph drawing can be glitchy when rescaling. Graphs are also redrawn when changing markers, even though they don't need to be.'

  • Sometimes markers begin behaving weirdly, e.g. markers to the right of the one being used moving the wrong way or too quickly, or markers getting out of order. To 'reset' them you can change the markers selection to none, then back again. This seems to happen most when markers are moved by hand quickly.

I'm not sure if these issues are showstoppers, but if anyone has suggestions to fix them let me know!

boxes do not inherit it. Flat buttons in dialog popups looks silly.

summary.html:
Resolve issue #25 by adding a delete keyboard shortcut to delete shots. Delete alone prompts for confirmation, shift+delete does not prompt.

Move stylesheet to central widget instead of main window, so that dialog boxes do not inherit it. Flat buttons in dialog popups looks silly.

values.description:
Allow shot files that specify (-1, -1, -1) (as per [labscript PR 48](#!/labscript_suite/labscript/pull-requests/48/marker-colour-enhancements)) as the marker colour to mean that no colour has been set, and default to black.

This PR does not change the behaviour of runmanager at all other than to suppress the warning Qt emits when it encounters rgb (-1, -1, -1), which it treats as black in any case.

Since this is pretty trivial I will merge it on Monday if there are no comments.
values.title: Compatibility with 'null' marker colours

This PR does not change the behaviour of runmanager at all other than to suppress the warning Qt emits when it encounters rgb (-1, -1, -1), which it treats as black in any case.

Since this is pretty trivial I will merge it on Monday if there are no comments.
summary.html:
Allow shot files that specify (-1, -1, -1) (as per labscript PR 48) as the marker colour to mean that no colour has been set, and default to black.

This PR does not change the behaviour of runmanager at all other than to suppress the warning Qt emits when it encounters rgb (-1, -1, -1), which it treats as black in any case.

Since this is pretty trivial I will merge it on Monday if there are no comments.

values.description:
(with backward compatibility - the resulting repo can still be just cloned into the python import path as is the case on existing labscript suite installs)

* Move files into standard Python package repository layout.

* Add setup.py, and shim modules for `__init__.py` and `__main__.py`. The shim `__init__.py` does a bit of magic to redirect the import to the package enclosed one level lower. The `__main__.py` runs `labscript_utils.winshell.fix_shortcuts()` if `labscript_utils` is new enough, and then runs the new shortcut. If `labscript_utils` is not new enough or if not on Windows, it runs the real `__main__.py` (in which case the user will get an error about `labscript_utils` not being new enough). This creates a pretty seamless upgrade - if one updates the existing runviewer repository within labscript_utils, everything will continue to work.

* Define `runviwer_dir` in `__init__.py` based on `__file__`. Use it for opening files in package dir: splash screen svg and .ui file. Do not chdir() at startup. Require labscript_utils 2.15.0 which has check_version and winshell functions compatible with the new repository layout.

* Recompile resample for Python 3.8 linux, windows 32 and 64 bit

This requires [labscript_utils PR #96](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/96/preparations-for-apps-to-be-restructured) for the `winshell` and `check_version` changes, and [labscript_utils PR #95](#!/labscript_suite/labscript_utils/pull-requests/95) for the change to not create log files in the package install directory..

With those two pull requests in `labscript_utils`, runviewer works as a regular PyPI package, I've uploaded it to `test.pypi.org`, and it can be installed with:

`pip install --index-url https://test.pypi.org/simple/ runviewer`

After running that and then `python -m labscript_utils.winshell --fix_shortcuts`, you'll be running runviewer from a regular package! But the repo is still entirely compatible with being run from within the labscript suite install directory.
values.title: Restructure into standard Python package

summary.html:
(with backward compatibility - the resulting repo can still be just cloned into the python import path as is the case on existing labscript suite installs)

  • Move files into standard Python package repository layout.

  • Add setup.py, and shim modules for __init__.py and __main__.py. The shim __init__.py does a bit of magic to redirect the import to the package enclosed one level lower. The __main__.py runs labscript_utils.winshell.fix_shortcuts() if labscript_utils is new enough, and then runs the new shortcut. If labscript_utils is not new enough or if not on Windows, it runs the real __main__.py (in which case the user will get an error about labscript_utils not being new enough). This creates a pretty seamless upgrade - if one updates the existing runviewer repository within labscript_utils, everything will continue to work.

  • Define runviwer_dir in __init__.py based on __file__. Use it for opening files in package dir: splash screen svg and .ui file. Do not chdir() at startup. Require labscript_utils 2.15.0 which has check_version and winshell functions compatible with the new repository layout.

  • Recompile resample for Python 3.8 linux, windows 32 and 64 bit

This requires labscript_utils PR #96 for the winshell and check_version changes, and labscript_utils PR #95 for the change to not create log files in the package install directory..

With those two pull requests in labscript_utils, runviewer works as a regular PyPI package, I've uploaded it to test.pypi.org, and it can be installed with:

pip install --index-url https://test.pypi.org/simple/ runviewer

After running that and then python -m labscript_utils.winshell --fix_shortcuts, you'll be running runviewer from a regular package! But the repo is still entirely compatible with being run from within the labscript suite install directory.
